FERNANDO TRASTÁMARA — PRINCE OF ASTURIAS

Intelligence: 82 — Brilliant

The boy who grabbed his father's beard upon their reunion grows into a mind of exceptional quality. Fernando learns to read early, devours books, asks questions that surprise his tutors. Languages, history, theology, natural philosophy—he absorbs knowledge like dry earth drinks rain. By the time he is ten, he will be correcting scribes' Latin. By fifteen, he will hold his own in theological debates with bishops. His father's intellectual intensity burns in him, refined and focused.

Temperament: 64 — Bold

There is nothing timid about Fernando. He speaks his mind, acts decisively, and meets the world with confidence. When other children hesitate, he steps forward. When courtiers equivocate, he states his position clearly. This boldness serves him well in council chambers and diplomatic negotiations—he does not flinch from difficult conversations or hard truths. Men respect his directness even when they disagree with his conclusions.

Martial Aptitude: 9 — Reluctant

And here is the shadow on the heir of Castile.

Fernando does not take to arms. The sword feels wrong in his hand. The violence of the training yard unsettles him. He learns what he must—a prince cannot be entirely ignorant of warfare—but he will never excel. He finds excuses to leave practice early. His instructors exchange concerned glances. By adolescence, squires younger than him will unhorse him in the lists.

For a kingdom forged in the Reconquista, for a father who led cavalry charges at Granada, for a dynasty whose legitimacy rests partly on martial prowess—this son, this heir, this Prince of Asturias... prefers books to swords.

It is not cowardice. Fernando is bold enough to face danger when he must. But he sees no glory in it, feels no thrill at the clash of steel. War, to him, is a failure of statecraft—a thing to be avoided through superior diplomacy, not celebrated through feats of arms.

Special Talent: 76 — Languages

What Fernando lacks in martial gifts, he possesses in abundance elsewhere. Languages come to him as naturally as breathing. Castilian, Latin, Portuguese, Catalan—by twelve. Italian, French, some Greek—by sixteen. Arabic phrases picked up from converted scholars. He hears a tongue spoken and something in his mind begins working, pulling apart patterns, assembling grammar, building vocabulary.

This is no mere parlor trick. A king who speaks to ambassadors in their own language, who reads foreign correspondence without translators, who can address subjects across a polyglot empire in words they understand—such a king wields a subtle but profound power.

Piety: 50 — Sincere

Unlike his sister Catalina, whose devotions ring hollow, Fernando believes. Not with the fervent intensity of a mystic or the burning certainty of a crusader—but with genuine, quiet faith. He prays because prayer matters to him. He attends Mass because he seeks God there, not merely because kings must be seen to worship. His faith is a foundation, not a performance.

This will comfort Juan immensely. Where Catalina's spiritual emptiness wounds him, Fernando's sincere devotion reassures. The heir to Castile believes in the God his father serves.

Physical Presence: 87 — Magnificent

And here is the cruelest irony.

Fernando grows tall. Broad-shouldered. Strong-limbed. He has the build of a warrior-king, the physical presence that makes men think "there stands a ruler." When he enters a room, eyes turn. When he sits a throne, he looks right there—as if God designed him to wear a crown.

He looks like everything a medieval king should be.

Except he cannot fight.

The magnificent body houses a scholar's soul. The hands that could grip a war-sword with authority prefer to turn pages. The frame that could anchor a cavalry charge would rather sit in a library. Men will see Fernando and expect El Cid reborn. They will find instead a polyglot philosopher who wins through words what other kings win through blood.

Some will call this weakness. Others, in time, may call it wisdom.

Fernando Trastámara — Prince of Asturias, heir to Castile and León.

A brilliant, bold, magnificently-built scholar-prince who speaks a dozen languages and believes sincerely in God—but who will never win glory in the lists or lead a cavalry charge with his father's fire.

The nursery at the Alcázar glows with evening firelight. Outside, February rain patters against the windows, but within, the room is warm, scattered with the detritus of childhood—wooden horses, a cloth doll missing one arm, blocks arranged into what Catalina has declared is Constantinople.

You sit with Lucia on a cushioned bench near the hearth, her hand resting on her belly where the newest Trastámara—still too small to quicken—grows in secret. The physicians have been sworn to discretion; there will be no announcement until the pregnancy is secure past the dangerous early months.

Fernando toddles among the blocks, nearly three years old now, tall for his age and sturdy. He has your chin, Isabel's dark eyes, and a physical presence that draws the gaze. When he moves, there is something certain about him—a solidity that seems to belong to a much older child. Doña Beatriz has remarked, more than once, that he looks like a prince from an illuminated manuscript.

"Polis," he says, pointing at the block-city. Then, switching without pause: "Ciudad. City." He looks up at Catalina for approval.

Catalina, four years old and already imperious, surveys her creation with the air of a master architect reviewing plans. "It needs walls," she declares. "Constantinople has walls. Papa said so. Muri magni."

"Teichē megala," Fernando offers—the Greek, imperfect but recognizable.

Lucia's hand finds yours. "He's been listening to you speak with the Byzantine envoys," she murmurs. "Three languages before his third birthday. Four, if we count the Portuguese he's picking up from the nurses."

In the corner, little Bianca—seventeen months old, wobbling on uncertain legs—crashes into a tower of blocks that Pedro, the son of one of your household knights, had been building. Pedro, seven years old and already conscious of rank, looks mortified but says nothing. Bianca laughs, delighted by destruction.

"Again!" she demands. "Ancora!"

Gonzalito, Pedro's younger brother, begins rebuilding the tower with the patient resignation of a child who has learned that princesses get what princesses want.

Catalina has found a wooden sword—left behind by one of the boys—and is swinging it experimentally. The movement is natural, her grip instinctively correct. She lunges at an imaginary enemy, her dark hair flying.

"Catalina," Lucia says mildly, "that's not—"

You touch her arm, and she falls silent. You have discussed this. Catalina will try what Catalina wishes to try.

Fernando watches his sister with the sword. One of the older boys—Gonzalito—offers him a smaller wooden blade. "Your Highness? Do you want to practice?"

Fernando considers the sword with those dark, thoughtful eyes. He takes it, holds it awkwardly, gives it one experimental swing. Then, very deliberately, he sets it down and returns to the blocks.

"I'm building," he says. "Aedifico."

Gonzalito looks uncertain. Boys are supposed to want swords. Princes especially. But Fernando is already absorbed in adding a tower to Catalina's Constantinople, murmuring to himself in a mixture of Castilian and Latin as he works.

Catalina, meanwhile, has graduated from lunging at shadows to demanding that Pedro spar with her. Pedro, caught between the impossibility of striking a princess and the impossibility of refusing one, looks desperately toward the adults.

"She's going to be a terror," Lucia observes quietly, watching your daughter advance on the hapless boy with her wooden blade raised. "A brilliant, beautiful, faithless terror."

Her voice carries no judgment—only observation, and perhaps a touch of rueful admiration.

"And him?" She nods toward Fernando, who is now explaining to Bianca—in simple Castilian mixed with Italian, adjusting his words to what his baby sister might understand—why the tower needs to be here and not there. "A scholar-king in a warrior's body. The nobles will expect him to lead charges. He'll want to lead negotiations."

The fire crackles. Rain drums against the windows. Your children play, each revealing in small ways the adults they will become.

Lucia leans her head against your shoulder. "God has a sense of humor, I think. Giving us exactly what we need—but never quite what we expect."
